summary: This 1940 West Africa Court of Appeal decision concerned a dispute over the validity of a mortgage and conveyance involving property devised under a will in Lagos, Nigeria. The testatrix, Elizabeth John, devised real property to Benjamin Young and his heirs in trust as family property, prohibiting sale or partition. Her executors granted a fresh mortgage post-death, and later, Young conveyed the property to Badaru Abina. The plaintiffs, Young’s children, sought to set aside the conveyance and mortgage, and demanded an account of rents. The court held that the Land Transfer Act 1897 was a statute of general application in Nigeria, empowering executors to mortgage the property. It affirmed the mortgage's validity but set aside Young’s conveyance. The court also ordered the mortgagee’s personal representatives to render an account of rents, recognizing their duty as equitable mortgagees in possession.
verdict: The appeal was allowed in part; the mortgage was upheld as valid, the conveyance was set aside, and an account of rents was ordered.

jurisdiction.country: Ghana (as part of British West Africa jurisdiction)

citations: Halsbury's Laws of England, Vol. XIV, para 685
Chief Young Dede v. African Association Limited
rationaleHighlights: The Land Transfer Act 1897 is a statute of general application and applies in Nigeria.
Executors have statutory power to mortgage property under the 1897 Act.
No native law or custom applied; English equitable principles govern.
Equitable mortgagee in possession must account for rents received.
Conveyance by beneficiary without legal title is void.
Section 20 of the Supreme Court Ordinance does not bar application of English statutes where native law is not involved.
